cdata.content: If you are thinking about harming yourself, call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline (press 1 if you are a Veteran). The lifeline is available 24/7 for free and confidential support.
Chat with National Suicide Prevention Lifeline
To text with a Crisis Counselor, reach out to the Crisis Text Line. The text line is free and available 24/7.
SAMHSA’s National Helpline is a free confidential information and referral service that is available 24/7 for individuals or families facing mental health or substance use problems.
The National Sexual Assault Hotline is available 24/7 for free confidential support and information about resources.
The National Domestic Violence Hotline is available 24 hours a day for anyone affected by abuse and needing support.

The Trevor Project is a national organization providing crisis intervention and suicide prevention services to lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer & questioning (LGBTQ) young people under 25. Help is available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.
Chat Online with The Trevor Project

The Childhelp National Child Abuse Hotline is a confidential 24/7 hotline with trained counselors that can offer support, information, and assistance reporting abuse. You can also chat with a counselor on their website.
The Stop It Now! Child Sexual Abuse Prevention Hotline offers confidential support, guidance, and information about how to prevent child sexual abuse. It is available Monday-Friday 12-6 EST.
Call Child Sexual Abuse Prevention Hotline

To report elder abuse or suspected elder abuse, you can contact local authorities, or call the Eldercare Locator. Eldercare Locator services are available from Monday to Friday, 9:00 am - 8:00 pm EST.
For more information regarding elder abuse and COVID-19, please visit the National Center on Elder Abuse website.
National Center on Elder Abuse & COVID-19
For additional state-specific information and hotlines, please visit the Elder Protection Center website.

It can be useful to connect with a therapist or counselor to help manage stress and mood symptoms. Many mental health providers are now offering remote video or telephone sessions, so that people can participate in therapy right from their own homes.
Finding a Provider if you have Insurance

Before connecting with a therapist, you may want to contact your insurance company to learn about any mental health benefits you might have. Your insurer may recommend certain therapists who are considered “in network” with your insurance. Or, you may have benefits that cover “out of network” therapists.
To locate a therapist near you, explore the links below.
Find a psychologist, therapist, counselor, social worker, or chaplain:
Search for a therapist or counselor
Search for a marriage and family therapist
Finding a Low-Cost or Free Provider

If you don’t have mental health benefits, you might look for therapists who see clients at a free, low-fee, or a sliding scale rate. Try searching for the following places in your community that likely offer free or low-cost virtual therapy:

content: Community mental health centers
Federally funded health care centers
Local universities or colleges that house training programs for therapists
National hotlines can often connect you to free local clinics
Counseling at places of worship
Employee Assistance Programs through work
Peer-support or recovery groups
Group therapy at local health clinics
State or county behavioral health services

cdata.content: 211 is a national database of resources that refers people to a local organization that can help them.
The National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI) offers free, virtual group resources.
The National Association of Free & Charitable Clinics and The Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA) have online databases with resources
National Association of Free & Charitable Clinics
For additional tools to help you manage stress and anxiety related to COVID-19, check out:

If you struggle with substance use or want to continue to get support in maintaining sobriety, the following resources may be useful during this tough time. Many support services and groups are now available virtually.
SAMHSA’s National Helpline is a free confidential information and referral service that is available 24/7 for individuals or families facing mental health or substance use problems

Narcotics Anonymous is a global, community-based nonprofit fellowship of recovering addicts who meet regularly to help each other stay clean. Check out their website for a directory of online meetings you can attend.

SMART Recovery is a global community that holds mutual-support groups for any addiction. Programs are science-based and emphasize self-empowerment for overcoming addiction. Check out their website for a directory of online meetings you can attend.

Alcoholics Anonymous is a global, community-based nonprofit fellowship of recovering alcoholics who meet regularly to help each other stay sober. Check out their website for information about online intergroups you can attend.
LifeRing is an organization of people who share practical experiences and sobriety support for overcoming drug and alcohol addiction. Check out their website for their online meeting schedule.

Cocaine Anonymous is a global, community-based nonprofit fellowship of recovering addicts who meet regularly to help each other stay clean. Check out their website for a directory of online meetings you can attend.
In The Rooms is a global online community who share strength and experience through live meetings, discussion groups, and other online tools.
Regularly updated list of financial resources and benefits.
Library Journal - When No Public Means No Paycheck
Finder for help paying bills, keeping utilities on, finding food.
How to apply for unemployment cash benefits.
How to apply for TANF cash and support benefits.

The Simple Dollar - Where to Find Financial Relief

Local community groups offering help with shopping, housework, paying bills.

Site for health care workers to request masks, and volunteers to send them.
Local community groups offering help with shopping, housework, paying bills.
COVID-19 Mutual Aid Groups: A List
Local community groups offering help with shopping, housework, paying bills.

Local community groups offering help with shopping, housework, paying bills.
Local community groups offering assistance with shopping, housework, paying bills.

How to Make a Face Mask

A website run by a team of researchers and clinicians to help navigate all the information about COVID-19 and provide credible and timely information about the pandemic. Responses to reader-submitted questions are posted on the site.
Official information about the pandemic from the US CDC.
Stay up-to-date on what the federal government is doing in response to the pandemic.
Stay engaged with VA information as it becomes available.
Johns Hopkins University Coronavirus Resource Center
Updates from public health and disease experts to inform the public.
American Association for Retired Persons (AARP) Coronavirus Updates
Tips and regular call-in events for older Americans.
National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI) Updates on the Coronavirus
NAMI provides tips for people with mental illness to enhance functioning during the COVID-19 outbreak.
Centers for Disease Control & SAMHSA - Managing Stress and Anxiety
Learn more from tips from the CDC and SAMHSA for dealing with stress.
Read the latest VA information regarding coronavirus and mental health.
The NCTSN provides resources for supporting children’s well-being during this time.
Talking to Your Children about School Closures
Learn more from the Washington Office of the Superintendent of Public Instruction about how to approach the topic of school closures with your children.
You can also call the National Parent Helpline for support related to stress or anxiety around parenting. Someone is available Monday through Friday from 10:00 AM PST to 7:00 PM PST.
Families who are expecting a child or who have recently welcomed a baby can access resources and support through Postpartum International.
The AARP also has morale-boosting resources for older adults.
The American Alzheimer’s Association provides information for people taking care of someone with dementia during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Give an Hour is a nonprofit group that provides access to low or no cost mental health services to address a variety of needs.
The VA offers a variety of services including healthcare, counseling, and benefits. Click below to find your nearest VA location.
VetCenters also have care for Veterans, and continue to serve Veterans during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Find your VA’s Caregiver Support Coordinator.
Women Veterans and their families can access a wide range of information and resources through the Center for Women Veterans (CWV), or can call or text the Women Veterans Call Center (WVCC).

Are you a family member of a Veteran?  Talk with an expert about how to help motivate your loved one  to try mental health care. The Coaching into Care telephone service is available from 8:00 AM to 5:00 PM EST, Monday through Friday.
Military OneSource offers information and support for members of the military and their families.
Answers to your questions about mental health from consultants who understand military culture.
Peer support for life challenges for the military community.
Learn about PTSD from Veterans and view video testimonials.
Comprehensive database of resources, tools, and services for Veterans, Service members, and their families.
Helpful medical news, information about programs, and links to TRICARE benefits and other services.
Confidential, free support from volunteer psychiatrists to help physicians with the unique stresses and mental wellness challenges of their work. Available 8am - 1am Eastern Time.
Stress and crisis counseling for health care and essential workers during the pandemic.
Free and low fee therapy for essential workers.
Peer-to-peer support for helping health care workers deal with professional distress and burnout.
American College of Physicians - Information for Internists
Guides, toolkits, and information for physicians providing care related to COVID-19.
American Hospital Association - Coronavirus COVID-19: Protecting & Enabling Health Care Workers
Resources for delivering care and protecting staff.
Support tips and lists of various services available to health care staff.

displayName: Mobile Apps to Support Mental Health

cdata.content: There are many different apps that could be used to help support mental health and well-being.
Here are just a few you could try:

Created by the National Center for PTSD, this is an app designed to help you bring mindfulness practices into your daily life. It offers guided meditation exercises, educational material, and a log for tracking your mindfulness practice.

An app designed for service members, veterans, and trauma survivors who  are experiencing symptoms of PTSD. This app provides educational material, interactive tools,  assessments to track symptoms over time, and important resources. It was developed by the National Center for PTSD and the Center for Telehealth and Technology.

An app designed for veterans and military service members, but it can be used by anyone coping with anger problems. AIMS provides users with education about anger, opportunities for finding support, the ability to create an anger management plan, anger tracking, and tools to help manage angry reactions. Users can also create custom tools based on their preferences, and can integrate their own contacts, photos, and music. AIMS was created by the National Center for PTSD and Mental Health Services at the Department of Veterans Affairs.

An app based on Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT), which aims to help you live with unpleasant thoughts, feelings, and impulses without avoiding them or being controlled by them. In ACT, you are encouraged to commit to actions so that you can live your life by your values, even in the face of these unpleasant experiences. The app offers exercises, tools, information, and tracking logs so you can practice what you’re learning in your daily life.

An app based on Cognitive Behavioral therapy for Insomnia (CBT-i) that teaches proven strategies for helping you improve your sleep. The app provides a structured program for learning about sleep, developing positive sleep routines, and improving your sleep environment.

An app designed to assist parents in talking to their children about disaster experiences. The provides information on how to explain, prepare, respond, and heal from ten types of disasters. It also provides guidance on how to support children when they are coping and reacting to disasters.
Mental health includes our emotional, psychological, and social well-being.  It affects how we think, feel, and act.
It also helps determine how we handle stress, relate to others, and make choices.  Mental health is important at every stage of life, from childhood and adolescence through adulthood.
Early Warning Signs of Mental Health Concerns
Not sure if you or someone you know is living with mental health problems? Experiencing one or more of the following feelings or behaviors can be an early warning sign of a problem:

content: Eating or sleeping too much or too little
Pulling away from people and usual activities
Having low or no energy
Feeling numb or like nothing matters
Having unexplained aches and pains
Feeling helpless or hopeless
Smoking, drinking, or using drugs more than usual
Feeling unusually confused, forgetful, on edge, angry, upset, worried, or scared
Yelling or fighting with family and friends
Experiencing severe mood swings that cause problems in relationships
Having persistent thoughts and memories you can’t get out of your head
Hearing voices or believing things that are not true
Thinking of harming yourself or others
Inability to perform daily tasks like taking care of your kids or getting to work or school
